The morning light, thin and fragile as a moth's wing, filtered through the solidified drop of resin that served as Pipkin's window. It was a Colchester light, carrying with it the faint, stony scent of Roman walls and the damp whisper of the River Colne. Pipkin stretched, his own wings, the colour of a dried cornflower, giving a sleepy flutter. They were his pride, meticulously preened and cared for, but they felt heavy this morning. Everything felt heavy. He slid from his bed—a hollowed-out puffball mushroom filled with milkweed silk—and his bare feet met the cool, smooth surface of the polished acorn floor.

His home, nestled in a gnarled fissure of the great oak that stood sentinel over Castle Park's western edge, was a place of order. Tiny scrolls of birch bark, inscribed with recipes for dew-distillates, were tucked into crevices. A loom, strung with the finest spider-silk, stood in the corner, a half-finished tapestry depicting the last great meteor shower shimmering upon it. Pipkin was a weaver, a craftsman of some repute. His specialty was capturing the first light of dawn in spun dew, creating threads that glowed with a soft, internal luminescence. But for the past week, the dew had been wrong.

He picked up his collecting-phial, a tiny vessel blown from sea-glass, and unlatched the bark-flap of his door. The air outside was still, but it lacked its usual crispness. It felt… used. Tired. He crept along the broad branch, his senses on high alert. Below, the park was beginning to stir. The distant rumble of the first human cars was a low growl on the horizon, but here, in the pixie enclave of Oakhaven, the only sounds were the rustle of waking dormice and the gentle sigh of the leaves. He found a perfect buttercup, its golden head bowed and heavy with the night's condensation. Normally, the dew here would be perfect spheres, each containing a miniature, upside-down world of impossible clarity.

Today, the droplets were misshapen, running together with a faint, oily sheen. When he touched the tip of his phial to one, it didn't siphon up with a clean pop; it slumped into the glass with a sullen reluctance. He held it up to the nascent light. The usual prismatic fire was gone, replaced by a dull, milky quality. It was like trying to capture light through a dirty window. A knot of anxiety tightened in his stomach. This was more than a bad batch. This was the Blight. Elderflower had spoken of it in hushed tones at the last gathering. A creeping insipidity, a slow draining of the world's magic. The berries were less sweet, the moonbeams less potent, the laughter of human children—a key ingredient in many potions—seemed to fade before it could be properly harvested.

He had just enough lackluster dew to mix his morning tea, a bitter brew of dandelion root that did little to lift his spirits. He had to visit the market. He needed a new spool of glow-worm silk, and his were the finest, sourced from a particularly artistic family of worms who lived beneath the Hollytrees Museum. The thought of the journey made his wings twitch nervously. The most direct route, the route any sensible pixie would fly, cut straight across the Great Pond.

And the Great Pond meant… them.

The mere thought sent a tremor through him. Ducks. The flat, vacant eyes. The unnervingly flexible necks. And that sound. That sudden, explosive, world-shattering *quack* that seemed to rip a hole in the very fabric of reality. He pressed his hands to the sides of his head. He could still remember it. A fledgling, barely old enough for solo flight, he had been showing off for his friends, swooping low over the water's glassy surface. He’d seen his own reflection, a flash of blue and gold, and then another reflection had surfaced beneath it. A monstrous, orange-beaked face, followed by an unholy noise that had sent him tumbling into the reeds, his wing bent, his heart hammering a rhythm of pure terror. He’d been trapped there for an hour, listening to them, a whole flotilla of them, paddling and muttering their demonic, watery language.

No. He couldn't. He wouldn't.

He would take the long way. The path that hugged the ancient Roman wall, a treacherous route of loose stones and skittering beetles, before cutting down through the prickly gorse near the children's playground. It would add an hour to his journey, but it was an hour free from the existential horror of webbed feet.

He secured his phial in his jerkin, pulled on his acorn-cap helmet, and launched himself into the tired air. The flight was sluggish. It took more effort than it should have, his wings beating against an atmosphere that felt thick and cloying, like invisible cobwebs. He landed on the crumbling top of the Roman wall, the stones still cool from the night. The city of Colchester spread out below, a patchwork of slate roofs and brick, but his eyes were fixed on the glint of water in the distance. Even from here, he could see them: dark shapes moving with serene, deliberate menace on the pond’s surface. He shivered, pulling his leaf-cloak tighter around his shoulders, and hurried on, his feet making soft pattering sounds on the ancient stone.

The market was a subdued affair. Usually, the central clearing of Oakhaven, located in the sheltered roots of a sprawling beech tree, was a cacophony of cheerful noise. Pixies haggling over the price of polished river stones, trading stories, sharing thimble-sized cups of nectar ale. Today, a pall hung over the proceedings. The stalls, usually overflowing with vibrant goods, looked diminished. The colours were less bright. A mushroom seller, a portly pixie named Finnian, showed Pipkin his wares with a sad shake of his head. "Look at them, Pip," he sighed, pointing to a basket of fly agarics. "The spots are practically grey. And they have no 'snap'. Just sort of… bend."

"It's the Blight," Pipkin said, his voice barely a whisper.

"It's a bad season," Finnian grumbled, though he didn't sound convinced. "The elders will sort it. They always do."

Pipkin wasn't so sure. He moved through the crowd, the general malaise a tangible thing. He saw his friend Bramble arguing with the glow-worm silk merchant. Bramble was stocky and practical, his wings the sturdy, functional brown of a winter moth. He believed in what he could touch and see, and had little time for anxieties.

"What do you mean the price has gone up?" Bramble boomed, his voice making a nearby pile of hazelnuts rattle. "It's thread, not spun gold!"

"The worms aren't eating," the merchant squeaked, wringing his tiny hands. "They say the soil tastes of nothing. Production is down. It's all I have."

Bramble threw his hands up in disgust and stomped over to Pipkin. "Can you believe this? The whole wood's gone mad. Bad dew, bland mushrooms, lazy worms. If this keeps up, we'll be patching our wings with cobwebs like common bog-sprites."

"It's the Essence," Pipkin insisted, his voice gaining a fraction of strength. "Something is breaking the cycle. Someone is using things up and not… returning them. The glamour-stones, the sun-motes, the echoes… they’re being discarded. Left to rot instead of being composted at the Great Root."

The Great Root was the heart of their world. A vast, underground network of roots from the eldest oak, where depleted magical items were placed. There, they would break down, their residual magic seeping back into the earth to be reborn as sparkling dew, sweet berries, and vibrant colours. To fail to return an item was the greatest taboo. It was an act of profound selfishness, creating a tiny pocket of magical decay, a void. And enough voids, the elders taught, would create a Blight that could unravel their world.

Bramble scoffed, though his eyes darted around nervously. "Who would do that? It's unthinkable. It's like a human just throwing their rubbish in the river." He shuddered at the thought. "No, it's just a phase. A planetary alignment. A cosmic grump."

Just then, a ripple of laughter passed through the market. A path cleared and Morwenna glided through, her wings a dazzling, impossible shade of iridescent amethyst. She was beautiful, everyone knew it. She moved with the easy grace of a pixie who had never known a moment of self-doubt. A crowd of admirers orbited her, hanging on her every word.

"Oh, it's all so dreary," she was saying, her voice like the chime of tiny bells. She gestured vaguely at the stalls. "Everyone's so worried. I say, if the nectar is weak, just add a drop of distilled hummingbird-fury! It gives it a wonderful kick."

She wore a cloak woven from the silver lining of a cloud, a notoriously difficult and energy-intensive material. At her throat was a pendant that caught the light with a fiery intensity: a perfectly preserved note from a wren’s song. It was an item of immense power, but temporary. Once its song was 'heard' by the wearer's spirit, it would fade to a grey husk. A husk that must, by law and custom, be returned to the Great Root.

Pipkin stared at her, a strange feeling prickling the back of his neck. Bramble nudged him. "See? She's not worried. Thinks we should all just drink stronger ale."

But Pipkin wasn't looking at her dazzling smile or her expensive cloak. He was looking at the very edges of her wings. There, almost too faint to see unless you were a craftsman who worked with light and colour every day, was a tiny, barely perceptible fringe of grey. A dusty, lifeless edge, like a flower petal just beginning to decay. It was the colour of his morning's dew. The colour of Finnian's mushroom spots. It was the colour of the Blight. And as she turned, laughing, he saw something fall from her belt. A small, grey, shrivelled thing, no bigger than a ladybug. It looked like a dried-up flower bud. But Pipkin knew what it was. It was the husk of a 'luck-blossom', its magic completely spent. Instead of tucking it away for later return to the Great Root, she had simply let it drop, and it landed with a silent puff of dust on the forest floor, another tiny tear in the fabric of their world.A cold dread, far deeper and more immediate than his fear of ducks, seized Pipkin. He froze, his gaze locked on the small, grey husk on the ground. It was an obscene thing, a tiny corpse of used-up magic left to rot in the open. The casualness of the act, the thoughtless flick of her wrist that had discarded it, was what truly horrified him. It was a gesture of supreme indifference. All around them, their world was sickening, and here was the source, dressed in amethyst and silver, laughing as she bled the life from it, drop by precious drop.

He grabbed Bramble’s arm, his grip surprisingly tight. "Bramble, look. She dropped it. Right there." He pointed a trembling finger at the ground near Morwenna’s glittering entourage. "A spent luck-blossom. She just… threw it away."

Bramble followed his gaze, squinting. "Threw what away? Pip, I don’t see anything." He was more interested in the way Morwenna’s laughter seemed to make the air shimmer around her. "You're getting yourself worked up. You need a good mug of honey-ale, that's your problem. Loosen you up." He tried to steer Pipkin towards the ale-stand, but Pipkin stood rooted to the spot, pulling his arm free.

"No! It was right there!" Pipkin insisted, his voice rising in pitch. He darted forward, ignoring the curious looks from other pixies, and knelt by the spot. But it was gone. A passing beetle, its shell a dull, Blight-leached brown, was trundling over the patch of earth, and the tiny husk had been kicked away, lost in the general detritus of the forest floor. He scrabbled in the dirt for a moment, his fingers closing on nothing but loose soil and fragments of dead leaves. He looked up, a desperate appeal in his eyes, but Bramble just shook his head with a look of pity.

"There's nothing there, Pip," he said, his voice softening as if speaking to a frightened fledgling. "Listen, this Blight talk has got you on edge. You're imagining things. Morwenna… she's a bit flashy, sure, but she's one of us. She wouldn't do that. It's just not done."

The dismissal was like a physical blow. Pipkin stood up slowly, dusting the soil from his knees. He looked from Bramble's well-meaning, uncomprehending face to Morwenna, who was now examining a necklace of firefly lanterns, her own light easily outshining theirs. He felt a profound sense of loneliness. He had seen it. He knew what he had seen. The Blight wasn't some cosmic accident; it was a choice. An accumulation of tiny, selfish choices made by a pixie who valued her own fleeting glamour above the health of their world. He saw her now not as beautiful, but as a parasite, adorned in the fading colours of the very life she was consuming.

The noise and chatter of the market suddenly felt unbearable. The haggling, the grumbling, the forced pleasantries—it all seemed like a charade. They were all standing in a house with rotting foundations, worrying about the colour of the curtains. He had come for glow-worm silk, but the thought of his loom, of weaving light, felt hollow now. What was the point of capturing the dawn if the dawn itself was dying? He turned away from Bramble without another word, the unspoken accusation hanging in the air between them.

He took flight, his wings beating a frantic, uneven rhythm. He didn’t care about the long way home now. He didn't care about the beetles on the Roman wall. He flew blindly, his mind a maelstrom of fear and fury. He had a secret now, a terrible piece of knowledge that set him apart from everyone else. The Blight had a face, and it was the most beautiful, celebrated face in all of Oakhaven. As he flew, he passed the edge of the Great Pond. Below, a squadron of ducks paddled in formation, their orange beaks like grim warnings. For the first time in his life, the sight of them didn't fill him with heart-stopping terror. It filled him with a strange, cold resolve. There were monsters in his world, he realised. He had just been afraid of the wrong ones.He didn't return to his hollow in the great oak. Not right away. The thought of its quiet, orderly solitude felt suffocating. His home was a testament to a world he had believed in, a world of reliable patterns and inherent magic. That world was a lie. He flew towards the sound of human activity, the low thrum of the city beyond the park's edge, letting the unfamiliar vibrations buffet his wings. He needed the noise, the chaos, something to drown out the silent scream of the discarded luck-blossom. He needed to feel that there was a world outside Oakhaven, a big, messy, indifferent world that would continue turning even if his own crumbled to dust.

He skirted the edge of the Hollytrees Museum, the very place where the lazy glow-worms lived. From a high branch of a sycamore, he could see the humans. They moved with such strange, lumbering purpose, their voices too loud, their movements too large. They discarded things constantly. Crisp packets, plastic bottles, paper cups. They threw them into designated bins, or sometimes, just onto the ground. Pipkin had always pitied them for it, for living in a world so disconnected from its own essence that they could treat it like a dustbin. Now, he saw a chilling parallel. Morwenna, with her careless grace, was no different from a human dropping a wrapper. The thought sent a new wave of sickness through him. The Blight wasn't just a pixie problem. It was a philosophy of use without renewal, a poison of the spirit that had somehow seeped into their sheltered enclave.

Finally, as the afternoon light began to thicken and turn gold, he knew he couldn't put it off any longer. He turned back towards the heart of the park, towards his home. And there it was, blocking his path like a vast, blue, unblinking eye: the Great Pond. His wings faltered mid-beat. His old, instinctual terror rose up, cold and sharp, threatening to send him spiraling back towards the safety of the Roman wall. He could see them, the dark shapes patrolling their liquid kingdom. His body wanted to flee, to take the long, safe path, the path of the coward.

But a new, colder feeling pushed back against the fear. It was the memory of Morwenna’s smile and the dusty grey fringe on her wings. It was the image of the spent blossom turning to dust on the uncaring ground. What was a duck compared to that? A duck was a loud, startling, brainless beast. The Blight was a slow, silent, all-consuming cancer. With a grim set to his jaw, Pipkin angled his wings and flew directly over the water. The air above the pond was cooler, carrying the scent of mud and wet feathers. Below, a mallard noticed his shadow. Its head, an iridescent green, snapped up. Its flat, orange beak opened. Pipkin braced himself. *QUACK!* The sound was as violent and tearing as he remembered. It ripped through the calm air, a sonic shockwave that made his bones vibrate. He flinched hard, his flight path dipping dangerously, but he did not fall. He clenched his fists, beat his wings harder, and forced himself onward. He had faced the unholy noise and survived. It was just a sound. The real horror was silent.

Back in the familiar quiet of his acorn-floor home, Pipkin felt like an intruder. His gaze fell upon the loom. The half-finished tapestry of the meteor shower, his attempt to capture a fleeting moment of cosmic magic, seemed a monument to his own naivety. He had been so proud of his craft, of his ability to spin light and dew into threads of beauty. But what was he but another consumer? He took the dew, he took the spider-silk, he took the light. He gave back beauty, yes, but the Blight proved that beauty was not enough. The cycle demanded more. It demanded return. He ran a hand over the shimmering threads. They felt cool and dead beneath his fingers.

He slumped onto his puffball bed, the milkweed silk compressing with a soft sigh. The anxiety in his stomach had not gone away; it had solidified, transformed from a fluttering panic into a hard, heavy stone of purpose. Bramble didn't believe him. The others were too dazzled by Morwenna to see the truth. The elders, bound by tradition and protocol, would demand proof he did not have. He was alone with this knowledge. If he did nothing, he would be complicit. He would watch the mushrooms turn grey, the nectar turn thin, and his own cornflower-blue wings fade to the colour of dust, all while knowing why. He would become just another pixie grumbling about a "bad season".

The thought was intolerable. He could not live in a world that was knowingly being murdered. He stood up, the movement sharp and decisive. He looked around his workshop, not as a weaver, but as something else. His eyes, trained to spot the subtle shifts in light and colour, to find the perfect dewdrop on a leaf, were his greatest tool. He was a craftsman of observation. And he would use that craft not to create, but to uncover. He needed to prove what he saw. He needed evidence that no one, not Bramble, not the Elders, not even Morwenna’s most ardent admirers, could deny. He needed to find her midden-heap, the secret graveyard of spent magic she must be keeping. A pixie so obsessed with her own pristine image would never allow such ugly, faded things to litter her own home. She had to be taking them somewhere. Somewhere secret. Somewhere dark. He would have to follow her. The idea was terrifying. It meant skulking in shadows, spying, abandoning the open honesty of pixie life. But as he fastened his acorn-cap helmet back on and checked the leather straps of his jerkin, he felt a flicker of something that had been extinguished within him: resolve. The Blight had a source, and he was going to find it.The first rule of spying, Pipkin decided, was patience. It was a quality he possessed in abundance, a prerequisite for a weaver who could spend a whole day waiting for a single sun-mote to drift into the perfect position for capture. But the patience of a craftsman was a calm, meditative state. The patience of a spy was a taut, humming wire of anxiety, a constant battle against the urge to fidget, to cough, to exist. He had found a perch in the shadowed upper branches of a dense holly bush, its prickly leaves a formidable camouflage. From here, he had a clear, if distant, view of Morwenna’s dwelling. It was, as he might have expected, a thing of blatant beauty: a large, luminous puffball fungus that glowed with a soft, internal light of its own, nestled on the most graceful bough of a silver birch tree. Lights from within cast dancing shadows, and the sound of laughter and music often spilled out into the night.

For three days, he watched. He learned her rhythms, which were no rhythms at all. She rose late, long after the precious morning dew had turned tired and flat. She entertained constantly, a shifting court of admirers flocking to her glowing home to sip on her potent cocktails and bask in her reflected glory. Pipkin watched, his stomach twisting, as she casually used items of potent, single-use magic to amuse her guests. She would conjure a brief, dazzling illusion of a phoenix, using a feather that crumbled to grey ash in her fingers afterwards. She would cool her drinks with frost-ferns that would, after a single touch of warmth, wilt into slimy black threads. And after each use, the spent husk would vanish. A flick of the wrist, a turn of the head, and the dead thing was gone, dismissed from reality as easily as it had been from her attention. He saw it, but it was always too quick, too subtle to be obvious to anyone not looking for it. To her guests, it was just part of the show.

His own life began to fray at the edges. The dust of disuse settled on his loom. His collecting-phial remained on its shelf, a monument to a morning ritual that now seemed pointless. He subsisted on dried berries and nuts, the flavour of which grew duller with each passing day. Once, Bramble found him in his holly-perch, his face grim. "Pip, what are you doing? You look awful. You're hiding in bushes like a fugitive grig. This isn't you." Pipkin couldn't meet his friend's honest, worried gaze. "I'm just… observing," he mumbled, the word tasting like a lie even though it was the truth. "The light is different from this angle." Bramble snorted in frustration. "The only thing that's different is you. Morwenna has you bewitched, one way or another. Come home, Pip. Weave something. The world will feel right again." Bramble didn’t understand. The world would never feel right again until this was resolved. He stayed in his bush, the distance between him and his friend widening into a chasm.

On the fourth evening, the pattern finally broke. The party at Morwenna’s home was louder and more dazzling than ever, celebrating, for no particular reason, the beauty of her new cloak woven from the iridescent scales of a dragonfly's wing. But as the last guest finally departed, their laughter fading into the quiet of the wood, Morwenna did not retire into her glowing home. She emerged a moment later, her bright cloak swapped for one the colour of shadow and bark. She moved with a furtive quickness he had never seen in her before, her usual languid grace replaced by a tense, hurried energy. After a long moment scanning the empty clearing below her tree, she launched into the air, not towards the market or the river, but towards the dark, tangled northern edge of the park. A jolt, sharp and electric, shot through Pipkin. This was it. This was the moment. He slipped from his hiding place, his own wings barely whispering against the air, and followed.

She flew low and fast, sticking to the deepest shadows. Her path led them away from the manicured lawns and familiar groves of Oakhaven, into a part of the park the pixies actively shunned. It was a place of tangled thorn-scrub and sullen, ancient yews, where the ground was perpetually damp and smelled of rot. Here, the distant hum of the human city was louder, and the earth was scarred with the remains of their carelessness—the rusted skeleton of a bicycle, a half-buried plastic sheet, the faint, chemical tang of discarded things. Pipkin felt a deep unease settle over him. This was a wounded place, a place where the natural magic of the world ran thin and sour. It was a place no pixie would ever choose to visit.

He landed silently in the gnarled branches of a skeletal hawthorn as Morwenna alighted on the ground below. She was standing at the edge of a hollow, a natural depression in the earth formed by the twisted roots of a dying yew tree. The bottom of the hollow was dark and wet, and a slick, rainbow sheen of pollution coated a puddle of stagnant water at its heart. It was a place of utter desolation, the spiritual opposite of the life-giving Great Root. Morwenna, the bright, beautiful centre of their world, looked around one last time, her silhouette a dark shape against the faint glow of the distant city lights.

Then, she reached to her side and unfastened a small, drab-looking pouch that had been concealed in the folds of her dark cloak. With a gesture that was both hasty and weary, she upended it. A stream of small, grey, lifeless things cascaded into the hollow. Pipkin didn't need to see them clearly to know what they were. He heard the dry, brittle rattle as they hit the damp earth: the sound of spent luck-blossoms, of wilted frost-ferns, of ashen phoenix-feathers, of the husks of a hundred other drained wonders. They were the collected ghosts of her glamour, a heap of magical corpses left to fester in unconsecrated ground. A wave of nausea and cold, clarifying rage washed over Pipkin. He watched as Morwenna, her burden lightened, gave a small sigh and took flight, heading back towards her pristine, glowing home, leaving the evidence of her sacrilege to rot in the darkness. He had his proof.For a long time after she was gone, Pipkin remained frozen in the hawthorn, the thorns like tiny daggers against his wings. The night was silent save for the distant, inhuman rumble of the city and the slow, wet drip of polluted water in the hollow below. The rage that had flashed so hot within him cooled into something heavier and more terrible: certainty. This was not a nightmare from which he could awake. It was the truth, and it was uglier than any monster his imagination had ever conjured. His fear of ducks seemed a childish, ridiculous thing now, a phantom terror from a world that no longer existed.

With a resolve that felt alien in his own body, he dropped from his branch, his landing so soft it made no sound on the blighted earth. He stood at the precipice of the hollow, the foul air rising to meet him. It was a miasma of decay, of sour earth and the chemical bitterness of human waste. It was the smell of the Blight itself, concentrated and raw. Holding his breath, he slid down the slick, root-choked embankment, his bare feet sinking into the cold, greasy mud at the bottom. The place was a wound in the world, and he was now standing at its heart.

The pile of husks was even more wretched up close. They were a monochrome jumble of grey and brown, all their former vibrancy and power leached away, leaving only these sad, brittle shells. He saw the crumpled ash of the phoenix feather, the shrivelled remains of a luck-blossom, and the unmistakable, faded form of a wren-song pendant, now just a dull, silent stone. These were not just objects; they were memories of magic, each one a tiny, extinguished star. Kneeling in the filth, a profound sorrow overwhelmed his anger. He reached out a trembling hand and picked one up—a sun-mote, once a speck of pure, captured daylight, now a fleck of grey grit that crumbled to dust between his fingers. He had failed it. They all had.

He couldn't leave them here. This was his proof. He unslung the small leather pouch from his belt, the one he normally used for carrying rare seeds or pigments, and began the grim task of collection. Each dead thing he touched felt like a betrayal, a violation. The silky texture was gone, replaced by a dry, rasping surface that felt like death. The faint, unique magical signature each item once possessed was now a uniform hollowness, a void that seemed to suck the warmth from his fingertips. He worked quickly, methodically, his craftsman’s precision now bent to this ghastly new purpose, scooping the magical detritus into his bag until the hollow was empty once more, leaving only the stained earth and the sheen of polluted water. The pouch, once light, now felt unnaturally heavy, a bag full of ghosts.

Clutching the evidence, he climbed from the pit. He did not fly towards his own quiet home, with its loom and its memories of a better time. He flew with a frantic, desperate energy, his wings beating a rhythm of pure fury, straight towards the sturdiest part of Oakhaven. He flew towards the solid, reassuring presence of his friend. Bramble’s home was not a thing of airy beauty, but of enduring strength. It was carved into the heart of a fallen log, its door a solid slab of oak and its window a sheet of clear, thick mica. It was a fortress, a home built by a pixie who believed in substance over style.

Pipkin didn't knock. He burst through the bark-flap door, bringing a gust of cold, foul-smelling air with him. Bramble, who had been carefully sharpening a thorn-knife by the light of a single, steady glow-worm in a jar, looked up in alarm. His stocky frame tensed, his hand tightening on the knife. "Pip! By the Great Root, what's happened to you? You smell like a bog-gurgle's midden."

Pipkin didn't answer. He walked to the centre of the room, to the flat, polished surface of the oak-stump table Bramble used for everything from dining to tool-mending. His hands were shaking so badly he could barely unfasten the tie on his pouch. "You said I was imagining things," Pipkin said, his voice a raw, broken whisper. "You said it was a bad season. A cosmic grump." With a convulsive gesture, he upended the pouch. The contents spilled out across the table with a dry, rattling sigh. The grey, lifeless husks of Morwenna's glamour spread across the wood, a field of dead magic under the steady, honest light of Bramble's glow-worm. The single point of light seemed to shrink from them, its glow turning pale and weak in their presence.

Bramble stared, his mouth slightly agape. He put down his knife and slowly approached the table. He recognised them, of course. Every pixie did. They were the common currency of ephemeral magic, the sort of trinkets one used for a flash of brilliance and then dutifully returned to the Great Root for renewal. To see one discarded was a taboo. To see a dozen was unthinkable. To see a hundred or more, piled together like common refuse, was a sacrilege of such magnitude it defied comprehension. He tentatively reached out a thick finger and touched the edge of a withered frost-fern. It flaked away into black dust. His gaze lifted from the pile of grey death on his table to the haunted, desperate eyes of his friend.

"She… threw them away," Pipkin choked out, the words tearing at his throat. "In the Thorn-Scrub, by the human rubbish. She has a secret dumping ground. I followed her. I saw her do it."

The bluff, easy confidence drained from Bramble’s face, replaced by a slow-dawning horror. He looked at the pile of evidence, then back at Pipkin’s filthy, mud-streaked tunic and the utter devastation in his eyes. There was no room for doubt. This was not a story. This was not a cosmic grump. This was real. He sank onto a nearby stool, his sturdy frame seeming to shrink. "Pip… I… I'm sorry," he breathed, the words heavy with shame. "I didn't believe you. I should have believed you." He swept his hand over the pile, not quite touching them, a gesture of profound dismay. "All this… just for a brighter cloak? A prettier illusion? While the rest of us deal with grey mushrooms and weak dew?" His voice, usually a booming baritone, was low and guttural with a rising, terrible anger. The Blight was not a force of nature. It was a crime. And they were looking at the evidence.Bramble's apology hung in the air, but it was his anger that truly filled the small, solid room. It was a tangible force, a heat that seemed to emanate from his sturdy frame, making the steady glow-worm in its jar flicker. He pushed himself up from the stool, his fists clenched at his sides. The practical, unflappable Bramble was gone, replaced by a pixie radiating a cold fury. He paced the short length of his home, his heavy footsteps thudding on the wood. "All this time," he growled, the sound a low rumble in his chest. "We’ve been tightening our belts, making do with less, telling ourselves it's just a cycle. And she's been living like a queen on a pirate's hoard, feasting on the magic and throwing the bones in a ditch."

He stopped and slammed a fist down on the table, making the grey husks jump. The motion was so violent it startled Pipkin out of his own daze. "We have to take this to the Elders," Bramble declared, his voice leaving no room for argument. "Now. This isn't a squabble over market prices anymore. This is a high crime. This is a rot that will kill us all if we don't cut it out." Pipkin nodded, a fresh wave of exhaustion washing over him now that he was no longer alone. The weight of the secret had been immense, but the weight of what they had to do next felt even greater. To accuse Morwenna publicly was to challenge the entire social fabric of Oakhaven. It was an earthquake, and they were the ones who had to trigger it.

With a grim sense of ceremony, Bramble fetched a large, clean dock leaf from a storage crevice. He spread it carefully on the floor, and together, they transferred the pile of magical refuse from his table onto the leaf. It was a somber, silent task. Bramble, with his usual brusque movements, was now uncharacteristically gentle, as if handling the pieces of a shattered soul. He folded the edges of the leaf over the pile, creating a neat, grim parcel. "There," he said, his voice tight. "The proof." He looked at Pipkin, his expression serious. "Are you ready for this? They'll question you. They'll try to find other explanations. Morwenna will deny everything. She'll smile and lie and make you look like a jealous fool."

Pipkin looked at the dark green parcel, the terrible weight it contained. He thought of his useless dew, of Finnian's grey mushrooms, of the weary sadness that had settled over their entire world. He thought of the dusty fringe on Morwenna’s perfect wings. "I know," he said, his voice steady for the first time that night. "But I have my craft. I know colour. I know light. And I know death when I see it. I will tell them what I saw." Bramble gave a single, sharp nod of approval. He strapped his thorn-knife securely to his belt, an act that spoke more of grim determination than of any real fear of violence. He was ready for a fight, even if it was one of words and reputations. Together, they stepped out into the pre-dawn stillness, leaving the sanctuary of Bramble’s home behind, and made their way towards the ancient heart of Oakhaven, where the Elders held their council.

The Chamber of Elders was not a building, but a space. It was a wide, circular clearing deep within the roots of the eldest oak in the park, the one the pixies called the Great Progenitor. The roots themselves, thick as a human's waist, formed the walls and ceiling, arching overhead like the vault of a cathedral. A soft, moss-green phosphorescence emanated from the wood itself, casting a solemn, timeless light on the proceedings. At the very centre of the chamber, a single, massive root descended from the ceiling but stopped just short of the floor. This was the terminus of the Great Root, the sacred place where spent magical items were returned to the earth. The air here was clean and vibrant, humming with a deep, resonant power—a stark, painful contrast to the sour rot of Morwenna's dumping ground.

Three Elders sat on thrones carved from living wood, their faces etched with the gravity of their office. There was Elderflower, her face a web of fine lines, her eyes deep and knowing. It was she who had first named the Blight. Beside her sat Rowan, stern and impassive, his wings the colour of granite, a traditionalist who valued order above all else. And finally, Hawthorn, the oldest of the three, whose wings were so faded and translucent they were nearly invisible, his gaze seemingly fixed on memories only he could see. They looked down as Pipkin and Bramble entered the chamber, their expressions unreadable. To request an audience with the full council at such an hour was an unprecedented act.

Bramble stepped forward, his solid presence a comfort to Pipkin. "Elders," he began, his voice echoing in the resonant space. "We have come with a heavy heart, and with grave news. We have discovered the source of the Blight." A ripple of surprise, faint as a moth's breath, passed between the Elders. Elderflower leaned forward slightly, her gaze sharpening with interest. Rowan's expression remained stony, skeptical. "A bold claim, Bramble," he said, his voice like the grinding of stones. "The Blight is a weakening of the Essence, a cosmic cycle. To claim a 'source' is to claim a culprit." Pipkin’s heart hammered against his ribs. This was it. Bramble looked to him, ceding the floor. Taking a deep breath of the pure, living air, Pipkin stepped forward and gently placed the dock-leaf parcel on the smooth, earthen floor at the foot of the Great Root. He knelt and slowly, deliberately, unfolded the leaf, revealing the pile of grey, lifeless husks.

A collective gasp, sharp and horrified, broke the chamber's solemn silence. The three Elders rose as one, their ancient eyes fixed on the obscene pile of dead magic. It was an open grave laid bare in their most sacred space. The soft green light of the chamber seemed to recoil from the husks, casting them in a harsh, unforgiving shadow. The vibrant hum of the Great Root faltered, replaced by a deep, mournful silence, as if the very heart of their world was crying out in pain. Hawthorn, the ancient one, took a shuffling step forward, his translucent wings trembling. He stared at the pile, a single tear tracing a path down his weathered cheek. "Sacrilege," he whispered, the word a dry rustle of leaves. "This... this is a wound. A wound made by a pixie hand." He looked at Pipkin, his old eyes now filled with a terrible, demanding clarity. "Speak, child," he commanded, his voice gaining a sudden, ringing strength. "Tell us who has done this thing."All eyes were on him. The weight of their gaze was heavier than any stone. Pipkin took a breath that tasted of clean earth and ancient magic, a stark contrast to the foulness of his recent task. He did not look at the Elders, but at the pile of grey husks on the floor, the silent victims he was there to represent. When he spoke, his voice was not the reedy whisper of a frightened pixie, but the clear, steady tone of a craftsman stating an undeniable fact.

“The one who did this is Morwenna,” he said, the name falling into the hallowed chamber like a black stone into a clear pool. The silence that followed was absolute, a vacuum in which the very hum of the Great Root seemed to have died. “I followed her last night, from her home to the Thorn-Scrub, to a polluted hollow by the old human ruins. She carried these in a pouch, concealed beneath a dark cloak. I watched her empty the pouch into the dirt and leave them there to rot. I saw it with my own eyes.”

Rowan’s stony face hardened further, his disbelief warring with the horrific evidence before him. “Morwenna?” he repeated, the name a protest. “She is a child of light. Her glamour brings joy to us all. You accuse her of this… this spiritual squalor? It is a monstrous charge, weaver.” But Elderflower held up a hand, her ancient eyes fixed on Pipkin, searching his face not for deceit, but for the truth of his pain. “The charge is monstrous because the crime is monstrous, Rowan,” she said softly. “The evidence lies at our feet. Joy can be a mask, and light can be stolen.” She turned her gaze to a young pixie guard near the entrance. “Summon Morwenna. She will answer this charge herself.”

It was not long before she arrived. Morwenna glided into the chamber, a vision of effortless beauty, her amethyst wings catching the moss-light and scattering it in a thousand dazzling fractals. She wore a simple morning gown of woven moonbeams, and her expression was one of mild, condescending amusement, as if she had been called away from a pleasant dream to deal with some trivial matter. “Elders,” she said, her voice a perfect silver chime. “You summoned me with such urgency. I do hope the sky is not falling.” Her eyes swept over Bramble, then landed on Pipkin, a flicker of contempt in her gaze. “Ah. Pipkin. I should have known. What dreary little anxieties have you brought to trouble the council this time?”

Her light, dismissive tone faltered as her gaze fell upon the drab, grey pile on the floor. For a fraction of a second, her mask of serene confidence slipped. A flash of pure, cold panic crossed her features before being expertly smoothed away. But Pipkin saw it. And he knew the Elders had seen it too. Elderflower gestured to the husks with a hand that trembled slightly. “These are the ‘dreary anxieties,’ Morwenna. They are the source of the Blight that sickens our world. Pipkin has testified that he saw you discard them, like common rubbish, in unconsecrated ground.”

Morwenna let out a laugh. It was a beautiful sound, but it didn't reach her eyes. “Pipkin? He saw me? Elders, with all respect, he is a lonely little weaver who spends his days squinting at dewdrops. He is consumed with envy for anyone who shines brighter than his threads. He’s been skulking in the bushes near my home for days. It’s no great feat of imagination for him to have gathered this… this trash… and concocted a story to tarnish my name.” She spread her hands, a picture of wounded innocence. “Look at me. Do I look like a creature who would traffic in such ugliness?”

“You wore a dark cloak to hide your journey,” Pipkin stated, his voice quiet but carrying in the stillness. “And the pouch was drab and made of leather, tied at your left side. "He has been spying! He admits it! A peeping grig, inventing fantasies to excuse his own sordid behaviour. What proof is there, other than the word of a jealous spy against mine?"

It was then that Pipkin took the final step, his fear burned away by the cold fire of certainty. He was a weaver of light. He knew its properties, its nuances, and its absence better than anyone. "The proof isn't just in the hollow, Morwenna. It's on you," he said, and he pointed not at her hands or her face, but at her most celebrated feature. “The Blight is a stain. A price. You have been consuming magic without returning it, and the debt has to be paid. Look at her wings.” A confused murmur rippled through the pixies who had gathered at the entrance, drawn by the summons. “Look at the very edges.”

For the second time, Morwenna’s composure broke. Her eyes widened in genuine terror, and she made an instinctive, telling move to fold her glorious wings, to hide them from view. But it was too late. Everyone followed Pipkin’s direction. Bramble stepped forward, squinting. Elderflower leaned over her throne. And in the solemn, honest light of the Elder Chamber, everyone could see it. It was a subtle flaw, easily missed in the dazzling glow of her parties, but unmistakable here. Bordering the vibrant, impossible amethyst of her wings was a thin, but distinct, fringe of dusty, lifeless grey. It was the colour of Finnian’s mushrooms, of the tired morning dew, of the dead husks on the floor. It was the mark of the Blight, the physical manifestation of the rot she had created, a decay she could no longer hide, no matter how brightly she shone. The spell of her beauty was broken, shattered by the quiet observation of a simple weaver. The murmuring from the crowd ceased, replaced by a single, horrified, collective gasp of understanding.The collective gasp hung in the air, a ghost of sound that seemed to suck all warmth and light from the chamber. Morwenna stood frozen, her desperate attempt to hide her wings only serving to confirm her guilt. The spell was broken. The dazzling illusion she had so carefully constructed around herself for years shattered, and for the first time, the assembled pixies saw not the icon of glamour, but the terrified, cornered creature beneath. Her face, usually a mask of serene beauty, twisted into a snarl of pure venom. The chime-like voice became a venomous hiss, directed not at the Elders, but at Pipkin.

“You!” she shrieked, the sound ugly and raw in the sacred space. “You did this! You couldn't bear to see something beautiful, could you? But her words, once so powerful, were now just noise. They bounced off the solemn roots of the chamber and fell dead at her feet, landing with as little impact as the grey husks she had discarded. No one was looking at Pipkin. All eyes were on the incriminating evidence of decay that fringed her own wings. The amethyst had turned to ash at the edges. Elderflower rose slowly from her throne, her expression one of profound, weary sorrow. “The Blight is not a flaw, Morwenna,” she said, her voice quiet but carrying the immense weight of her authority. “It is a wound. Rowan, his face a grim mask of judgment, stepped forward. “The law of the Great Root is the first and most sacred of our laws. It is not complex. You take, you use, you return. Morwenna began to weep, but her tears were those of self-pity, not remorse, and they garnered no sympathy. “The sentence,” Rowan continued, his voice ringing with finality, “must be one of restoration. Morwenna flinched but did not resist, her fight extinguished. “Your penance,” Rowan went on, his gaze unrelenting, “will be to undo the harm you have caused.
